battery.notes: Smartphone batteries can be reused in DIY projects if they still hold a charge. Ensure proper storage to prevent swelling.

camera.notes: Higher value for newer models or undamaged lenses. Camera modules can be repurposed for DIY projects.

charging_port.notes: USB-C ports have higher reuse value than older micro-USB ports.

speaker.notes: Stereo speakers or those from premium devices have higher value.

vibrator.notes: Linear vibration motors have higher precision and value.

logic_board.notes: Value depends heavily on processor generation and physical condition.

nodes.text: What type of smartphone do you have?

Apple iPhone Disassembly

# Initial Preparation
- Please first power off the device before proceeding with the disassembly.
- Remove the sim card tray and external accessories connected to the device.

## Battery
**WARNING**: Batteries are made out of lithium-ion, which can be dangerous if punctured or damaged. It is advised to let professionals handle this type of battery. Do you still want to proceed?

steps.action: Locate the battery connector (usually found near the logic board). If there is a metal shield over the battery connector, remove it using a precision screw.
Disconnect the battery connector using a non-metallic pry tool.

options.label: Are there pull-tabs or adhesive strips?

nodes.text: Are there any pull-tabs or adhesive strips on the battery?

steps.action: Slowly and firmly pull the adhesive strips at a shallow angle, keeping them parallel to the phone’s base.
Once loosened, gently lift the battery.

If it's hard to pull, apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges. Let it sit for 1-2 minutes to soften the adhesive. Use a plastic tool to gently pry off the battery.
Apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges.
Let it sit for a few minutes to soften the adhesive.
Use a plastic pry tool then gently lift the battery from the housing.

nodes.text: Once the battery is dismantled, store the batteries safely in a fireproof container. Do not bend, puncture, or expose the battery to high temperatures.
Which camera do you want to extract?

steps.action: Locate the rear-facing camera (usually at the top right).
If there are any mounting brackets securing the module, unscrew it.
Disconnect the flex cables near the rear-camera module carefully.
Gently lift the rear-camera module.
Remove or lift the display (if not already done). Carefully open the screen using a plastic spudger and suction cup. Be mindful of flex cables attached near the top of the display.
Locate the front camera module at the top edge of the screen assembly, embedded in a black flex cable cluster.
Remove any brackets or shields using a precision screwdriver.
Disconnect the front camera flex cable using a plastic pry tool.
Gently lift the camera module using plastic tweezers or a spudger. If glued, apply a drop of isopropyl alcohol (90%+) and wait 30–60 seconds before lifting.

nodes.text: Avoid touching the camera lens to avoid smudges or scratches. Store the cameras in a dust-free container.

steps.action: Use a plastic spudger to disconnect all visible flex cables linked to the charging port assembly.
Use a precision screwdriver to remove all fasteners securing the charging port or its flex cable.
If the flex cable is glued to the frame, apply 90% or higher isopropyl alcohol along the edges. Wait 1–2 minutes to allow the adhesive to soften.
Use a plastic card or tweezers to gently lift and peel away the entire charging port flex cable. Be extra cautious — the film sections are delicate and may tear if lifted abruptly.
Disconnect all visible flex cables connected to the logic board using a plastic spudger.
Remove metal shields or brackets covering connectors or chips with a precision screwdriver.
Unscrew the logic board from the device frame (usually 2–5 screws).
Check for hidden connections. Ensure all flex cables and antennas are fully detached before lifting.
Gently lift the logic board using plastic tweezers or a spudger. Start from the bottom edge and lift slowly.
Locate the speaker module at the bottom of the device, near the charging port.
Check for overlapping components (metal brackets, antenna connectors, plastic spacer). Remove these gently using tweezers or a spudger.
Remove any screws securing the speaker. Use a precision screwdriver (Philipps #000 or Tri-point).
Disconnect the flex cables connected to the speaker using a plastic pry tool or spudger.
Gently pry from one edge and lift the speaker module straight up.
Locate the vibrator motor (Taptic Engine) near the lower portion of the iPhone.
Unscrew any mounting brackets securing the motor in place.
Once unscrewed, gently lift the motor straight up. Avoid pulling or bending the flex cable connected to the motor.
Disconnect the flex cable attached to the motor using a plastic pry tool.
